summary: This document is an email chain from July 20, 2021, between a journalist (Dipesh Gadher) and U.S. Attorney's Office personnel regarding the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The journalist seeks clarification on trial details, sentencing, the ongoing investigation, and Prince Andrew's status. The internal responses show coordination on public messaging, specifically to decline comment on Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Dipesh Gadher
persons.context: The journalist who sent the initial email inquiry to the U.S. Attorney's Office seeking updates on the Ghislaine Maxwell case, including questions about trial structure, sentencing, the ongoing investigation, and Prince Andrew.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The subject of the email inquiry. The document discusses the severance of her sex abuse and perjury charges into two trials, the November trial date for sex abuse counts, and the maximum potential sentence.

persons.name: Prince Andrew
persons.context: Referenced in the journalist's question (#6) asking if he remains a person of interest in the ongoing investigation into Epstein's network and if US prosecutors have obtained a statement from him. The internal response indicates a strategy to decline comment on him.

persons.name: Judge Nathan
persons.context: Mentioned as the judge who severed the sex abuse and perjury counts against Ghislaine Maxwell into two separate trials.

connections.description: Implied connection through the investigation into Epstein's network; Prince Andrew is referenced as a potential person of interest in that ongoing investigation.
Journalist seeking information from the U.S. Attorney's Office for a story on Maxwell's legal proceedings.

events.title: Email Inquiry on Maxwell Case
events.description: Journalist Dipesh Gadher emails the U.S. Attorney's Office with six specific questions about the status of the Ghislaine Maxwell case, including trial details and Prince Andrew.

events.title: Scheduled Start of Maxwell Sex Abuse Trial
events.description: The sex abuse trial for Ghislaine Maxwell is scheduled to begin in November 2021, as confirmed in the email chain. The perjury trial date is not yet set.

events.title: Severance of Maxwell's Charges
events.description: Judge Nathan severed the charges against Ghislaine Maxwell, creating two separate trials: one for sex abuse charges (1994-2004) and another for perjury charges (2016).

locations: London Bridge Street, London SE1 9GF (The Sunday Times office)
keyFacts: Judge Nathan severed the charges against Ghislaine Maxwell, resulting in two separate trials: one for sex abuse (1994-2004) and one for perjury (2016).
As of July 2021, the sex abuse trial was scheduled for November 2021, while no date was set for the perjury trial.
The journalist explicitly asked if Prince Andrew remained a "person of interest" in the ongoing investigation into Epstein and Maxwell's network.
Internal communications among U.S. Attorney's Office staff show a coordinated strategy to "decline any further comment on Andrew."
The maximum sentence previously discussed for Maxwell was "up to 80 years behind bars."
